list.title: Question 1
list.content: Which of the following statements isfalse?I.\hspace{1em}Electrons have greater mass than protons and neutronsII.\hspace{1em}Protons and neutrons are in the nucleusIII.\hspace{1em}Protons and electrons are charged subatomic particlesIV.\hspace{1em}Electrons are located outside the nucleusA.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyB.\hspace{1em}II and IV onlyC.\hspace{1em}II onlyD.\hspace{1em}I only
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Electrons have negligible mass.

list.title: Question 2
list.content: The nuclear symbol for an isotope of iodine isX53125X2532125I\ce{^{125}_{53}I}X53125​X2532125​I. Which of the following is correct about the isotope?Atomic NumberMass NumberNumber of protonsNumber of neutronsNumber of electrons\hspace{1em}A.\hspace{1em}53125537253\hspace{1em}B.\hspace{1em}53125725353\hspace{1em}C.\hspace{1em}12553537272\hspace{1em}D.\hspace{1em}12553535372
list.markScheme:
AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/42307e35-8608-4db2-8772-65b60ebe1e65/images/67b4491b-77e7-4bdb-ab9a-3bfc9f01f1dd/2.1-48.png)

The mass number is the sum of the number of protons and neutrons. For a neutral atom, the number of electrons is equal to the number of protons.

list.title: Question 3
list.content: The atom of an element Q has an atomic number of 27 and a mass number of 60. Which of the following statements is true about the subatomic particles of the atom of element Q?I.\hspace{1em}Atom of element Q has 27 electrons and 60 protonsII.\hspace{1em}Atom of element Q has 27 protons and 27 electronsIII.\hspace{1em}Atom of element Q has 27 electrons and 60 neutronsIV.\hspace{1em}Atom of element Q has 27 protons and 33 neutronsA.\hspace{1em}I and IV onlyB.\hspace{1em}II and IV onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I and III only
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The atomic number is the number of protons. The mass number is the sum of the number of protons and neutrons. For a neutral atom, the number of electrons is equal to the number of protons.

list.title: Question 4
list.content: Which of the following is not a physical property of an isotope of an element with fewer neutrons in its atom?A.\hspace{1em}Lower massB.\hspace{1em}Faster rate of diffusionC.\hspace{1em}Higher densityD.\hspace{1em}Lower melting and boiling points
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Isotopes with fewer neutrons will have a lower density

list.title: Question 5
list.content: Isoelectronic species are atoms or ions with the same number of electrons. Which of the following are isoelectronic species?I.AlX3+\ce{Al^3+}AlX3+II.MgX2+\ce{Mg^2+}MgX2+III.OX2−\ce{O^2-}OX2−A.\hspace{1em}I and IIB.\hspace{1em}II and IIIC.\hspace{1em}I and IIID.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: DExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​The correct answer is that all three species are isoelectronic. Isoelectronic species have the same number of electrons despite being different elements or ions. Aluminum in its neutral state has 13 electrons, but when it loses three electrons to formAlX3+,\ce{Al^{3+}},AlX3+,it has 10 remaining electrons. Magnesium has 12 electrons when neutral, and when it loses two to formMgX2+,\ce{Mg^{2+}},MgX2+,it also has 10 electrons. Oxygen, on the other hand, has 8 electrons in its neutral state, but when it gains two to formOX2−,\ce{O^{2-}},OX2−,it reaches a total of 10 electrons. Since all three ions have ten electrons, they are isoelectronic.

list.title: Question 6
list.content: The isotopes of carbonX12X2212C\ce{^{12}C}X12​X2212​CandX13X2213C\ce{^{13}C}X13​X2213​C:I.\hspace{1em}have the same atomic numberII.\hspace{1em}have the same physical propertiesIII.\hspace{1em}have the same chemical propertiesA.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Isotopes are atoms of the same element with different numbers of neutrons that differ only in terms of their physical properties.

list.title: Question 7
list.content: How many electrons are there inX1735X217235ClX−\ce{^{35}_{17}Cl^-}X1735​X217235​ClX−?A.\hspace{1em}17B.\hspace{1em}18C.\hspace{1em}35D.\hspace{1em}36
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The atomic number is 17, hence there are 17 protons and 17 electrons in the atom (since atom is neutral). The ion with a charge of (1-) means that the atom has gained 1 electron and therefore, contains 18 electrons.

list.title: Question 8
list.content: The following table shows the number of subatomic particles present in five species.SpeciesNumber of protonsNumber of neutronsNumber of electronsR888S8810T9108U101010V101210Which two species are isotopes of the same element?A.\hspace{1em}R and SB.\hspace{1em}S and TC.\hspace{1em}T and UD.\hspace{1em}U and V
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Isotopes have the same number of protons but different numbers of neutrons.Species R and S have the same number of protons but also the same number of neutrons so cannot be isotopes. S is an anion of element R.Species T is the only species in the table with 9 protons so cannot have an isotope with another species in the table because it is a different element.This leaves speciesU and Vwhich both have the same number of protons but a different number of neutrons so they are isotopes.

list.title: Question 9
list.content: Which of the following statements aboutX2351X223251V\ce{^{51}_{23}V}X2351​X223251​Vare correct?I.It has 23 protonsII.It has 51 nucleonsIII.It has a condensed electron configuration of [Ne]4s23d34s^2\,3d^34s23d3A.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Vanadium has an atomic number of 23 therefore statement I is true. It also has a mass number of 51, therefore statement II is also true as nucleons include both protons and neutrons. Statement III is false as the closest noble gas is Ar, not Ne. The correct condensed electron configuration would be [Ar]4s23d34s^2\,3d^34s23d3. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

list.title: Question 10
list.content: What happens to an atom if it loses two electrons?A.\hspace{1em}It becomes a positively charged cation with a charge of2+.2+.2+.B.\hspace{1em}It becomes a positively charged anion with a charge of2+.2+.2+.C.\hspace{1em}It becomes a negatively charged anion with a charge of2−.2-.2−.D.\hspace{1em}It becomes a negatively charged cation with a charge of2−.2-.2−.
list.markScheme: AExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​When an atom loses two electrons, it becomes a positively charged cation with a charge of2+.2+.2+.Atoms are electrically neutral when they have equal numbers of protons and electrons. However, when electrons are removed, the balance shifts, leaving more positively charged protons than negatively charged electrons. The result is the formation of a cation, or positively charged ion. Since two electrons are lost, the charge on the resulting ion is2+,2+,2+,indicating that the number of protons exceeds the number of electrons by two.

list.title: Question 11
list.content: An atom has the nuclear symbolX1735X217235X.\ce{^{35}_{17}X}.X1735​X217235​X.Which statement is correct?A.\hspace{1em}It has 17 protons, 17 neutrons, and 17 electrons.B.\hspace{1em}It has 17 protons, 18 neutrons, and 17 electrons.C.\hspace{1em}It has 17 protons, 18 neutrons, and 18 electrons.D.\hspace{1em}It has 18 protons, 17 neutrons, and 17 electrons.
list.markScheme: B`Explanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​When identifying a isotope, the chemical symbol is written alsoXZAX2Z2AX\ce{_Z^A X}XZA​X2Z2A​XwhereZZZis the atomic number, or number of protons andAAAis the mass number, thes sum of the number of protons and neutrons.In the isotopeX1735X217235X,\ce{^{35}_{17}X},X1735​X217235​X,the atomic number is 17.  There are 17 protons in the nucleus. The mass number is 35. This is the sum of protons and neutrons. To find the number of neutrons, subtract the atomic number from the mass number:35−17=1835 - 17 = 1835−17=18neutrons. Since this is a neutral atom, the number of electrons is equal to the number of protons, meaning it also has 17 electrons.

list.title: Question 12
list.content: Bromine has 2 stable isotopes: bromine-79 and bromine-81. What is the relative atomic mass of bromine (Br)?IsotopeRelative AbundanceAtomic Mass79^{79}79Br50.69%78.9281^{81}81Br49.31%80.92A.\hspace{1em}78.5B.\hspace{1em}80.1C.\hspace{1em}81.2D.\hspace{1em}79.9
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Relative atomic mass ofBr=(0.5069)(78.92)+(0.4931)(80.92)=79.Br = (0.5069)(78.92) + (0.4931)(80.92) = 79.Br=(0.5069)(78.92)+(0.4931)(80.92)=79.9. The rest of the choices are incorrect relative atomic masses of bromine.Alternative Method‾\underline{\textrm{Alternative Method}}Alternative Method​:79^{79}79Br atomic mass can be rounded up to 7981^{81}81Br atomic mass can be rounded up to 81Since the relative abundance of both isotopes is about 50% each, the relative atomic mass of Bromine should be close to 80. Choice D corresponds to that estimation.

list.title: Question 13
list.content: The atom of element X has a mass number of 127 and has 74 neutrons. The ion derived from X has 54 electrons.Calculate the number of protons of element X.[1]State the nuclear symbol of the ion formed (refer to the periodic table).[2]An isotope of X has a mass number of 132. Determine the number of neutrons in its atom.[2]
list.markScheme: Number of protons = 127 – 74 =53✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​Number of protons (ZZZ) = mass number(AAA) – number of neutrons(NNN)Nuclear symbol:53127I_{53}^{127}\textrm{I}53127​I−^{-}−✓\checkmark✓✓\checkmark✓Note:Onemarkforthechargeandonemarkforthenuclearsymbol.\textit{Note: One mark for the charge and one mark for the nuclear symbol.}Note: One mark for the charge and one mark for the nuclear symbol.Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The atomic number of the element X is 53 (number of protons). Therefore, it corresponds to iodine with a mass numberA=127A= 127A=127(referring to the periodic table). The number of electrons in the ion formed is 54. This means that the atom has gained one electron, and the overall charge of the ion is(1−).(1-).(1−).Since it is an isotope, the number of protons is the same for all atoms of isotopes of the same element.✓\checkmark✓Number ofneutrons=132−53=\textrm{neutrons} = 132 - 53 = \neutrons=132−53=79 neutrons✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​number of neutrons = mass number−-−number of protons

list.title: Question 14
list.content: The following table shows the number of subatomic particles present in five different species.SpeciesNumber of protonsNumber of neutronsNumber of electronsR888S11810T9108U101010V121012Which species are ions?A.\hspace{1em}R and SB.\hspace{1em}S and TC.\hspace{1em}T and UD.\hspace{1em}U and V
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Ions of an element do not have the same numbers of protons and electrons.Only speciesS and Tdo not have the same number of protons and electrons, so they are ions.Note: S and T are not ions of the same element, but both have nonzero charge so are considered ions.

list.title: Question 15
list.content: Which combination is correct forX1941X219241K+?\ce{^{41}_{19}K{^+}}?X1941​X219241​K+?\\hspace{1.em}Number of protonsNumber of neutronsNumber of electronsA.192218B.192220C.224120D.221918
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The nuclear symbol notation allows to deduce the number of protons, neutrons and electrons.XZAX2Z2AXXq\LARGE{\ce{_Z^A X^q}}XZA​X2Z2A​XXqXChemical symbol\textrm{Chemical symbol}Chemical symbol\hspace{0.1em}A\mathbf{A}AMass numberprotons + neutronsZ\mathbf{Z}ZAtomic numberprotonsq\mathbf{q}qChargeprotons−-−electronsIn this symbol:Z=19\textrm{Z} = 19Z=19, the number of protons.A=41\textrm{A} = 41A=41, there are41−19=2241 - 19 = 2241−19=22neutrons.q=+1\textrm{q} = +1q=+1, there are19−1=1819-1=1819−1=18electrons.This question is categorized as easy as students must be able to calculate the number of protons, neutrons, and electrons by interpreting the nuclear symbol notation.

list.title: Question 16
list.content: Complete the following table:Nuclear SymbolNumber of protonsNumber of neutronsNumber of electrons62153Sm_{62}^{153}\textrm{Sm}62153​Sm62811202656Fe2+_{26}^{56}\textrm{Fe}^{2+}2656​Fe2+2646103Pd_{46}^{103}\textrm{Pd}46103​Pd46161618
list.markScheme: One mark✓\checkmark✓per rowNuclear SymbolNumber of protonsNumber of neutronsNumber of electrons62153Sm_{62}^{153}\textrm{Sm}62153​Sm62916281201Tl_{81}^{201}\textrm{Tl}81201​Tl81120812656Fe2+_{26}^{56}\textrm{Fe}^{2+}2656​Fe2+26302446103Pd_{46}^{103}\textrm{Pd}46103​Pd4657461632S2−_{16}^{32}\textrm{S}^{2-}1632​S2−161618Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​In a neutral atom nb of protons = nb of electrons;Mass number A= Z +N;     N= A - ZZAXcharge_{Z}^{A}\textrm{X}^{charge}ZA​Xcharge, X being the symbol of the element

list.title: Question 17
list.content: Fluorine isotopes are used in PET scans to detect cancer. A sample used in one scan contains two isotopes of fluorine:Fluorine isotopeMass (amu)% abundanceIsotope 118.0065%Isotope 2X35%The relative atomic mass of the fluorine in this sample is 18.35.Determine the number of protons, neutrons and electrons in a neutral atom of isotope 1.[1]State the relative mass and charge of each subatomic particle.[2]Calculate the mass of isotope 2.[1]Predict and explain one physical property that differs between the two isotopes.[2]
list.markScheme: protons 9, neutrons 9,ANDelectrons 9✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The atomic number of fluorine is 9, so every fluorine atom has 9 protons. Isotope 1 has a mass number of 18, so it contains18−9=918 - 9 = 918−9=9neutrons. In a neutral atom, the number of electrons is equal to the number of protons, so it has 9 electrons.charges: proton = +1, neutron = 0ANDelectron =−1✓-1\ \checkmark−1✓masses: proton = 1, neutron = 1ANDelectron∼0\sim 0∼0/ negligible✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The SI units for the masses and charges of the elementary particles are in the data booklet.Neutrons are uncharged.  Protons and electrons have charges±1.602177×10−19textC.\pm 1.602177\times 10^{-19}text{ C}.±1.602177×10−19textC.Dividing by the fundamental unit of charge gives the typical charges: proton = +1, neutron = 0, and electron =−1.-1.−1.Neutrons and protons have similar masses:mn=1.674927×10−27kgm_n = 1.674927\times 10^{-27}\text{ kg}mn​=1.674927×10−27kgandmp=1.672622×10−27kgm_p = 1.672622\times 10^{-27}\text{ kg}mp​=1.672622×10−27kgwhile electrons are more than one thousand times smaller,me=9.109384×10−31kg.m_e = 9.109384\times 10^{-31}\text{ kg}.me​=9.109384×10−31kg.Dividing by the fundamental unit of mass, 1/12th^\text{th}ththe mass of a carbon–\text{--}–12 atom,1.66054×10−27kg,1.66054\times 10^{-27}\text{ kg},1.66054×10−27kg,the masses in atomic mass units can be determined: proton = 1.0073, neutron = 1.0087, and electron = 0.0005.  In IB Chemistry, we typically use the simpler values proton = 1, neutron = 1, and electron∼0\sim 0∼0.18.35=(0.65)(18.00)+0.35x;x=19.0018.35 = (0.65)(18.00) + 0.35x\ ;\quad x = 19.0018.35=(0.65)(18.00)+0.35x;x=19.00Further Explanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The relative atomic mass is the weighted average of the isotopic masses.Ar=65×18.00+35×x100=18.35A_r = \dfrac{65 \times 18.00 + 35 \times x}{100} = 18.35Ar​=10065×18.00+35×x​=18.35x=19.00x = 19.00x=19.00any one of the following physical properties:isotope 2 has a slower diffusion rate✓\checkmark✓isotope 2 has a higher density✓\checkmark✓isotope 2 has a (slightly) higher boiling/melting point✓\checkmark✓isotope 2 has a higher mass✓\checkmark✓Allow the opposite about isotope 1.Further Explanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​Even though both isotopes of fluorine behave the same chemically, physical properties can vary due to their different masses. Isotope 2 has one extra neutron, making it slightly heavier.This would lead to a slower diffusion rate (heavier atoms move more slowly), higher density, and a slightly higher boiling or melting point.

list.title: Question 18
list.content: Which isotope has the greatest number of neutrons?A.X614X26214C\hspace{1em}\ce{^14_6C}X614​X26214​CB.X816X28216O\hspace{1em}\ce{^16_8O}X816​X28216​OC.X918X29218F\hspace{1em}\ce{^18_9F}X918​X29218​FD.X1020X210220Ne\hspace{1em}\ce{^20_10Ne}X1020​X210220​Ne
list.markScheme: DExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​The number of neutrons in an atom can be found using the following formula:Mass number = # protons + # neutronsIn the isotopes written in this question, the top number is the mass number and the lower number is the atomic number which equals the number of protons. Therefore, the number of neutrons for each is:IsotopeMass NumberAtomic NumberProtonsNeutronsX614X26214C\ce{^14_6C}X614​X26214​C146614−6=814-6=814−6=8X816X28216O\ce{^16_8O}X816​X28216​O168816−8=816-8=816−8=8X918X29218F\ce{^18_9F}X918​X29218​F189918−9=918-9=918−9=9X1020X210220Ne\ce{^20_10Ne}X1020​X210220​Ne20101020−10=10\mathbf{20-10=10}20−10=10

list.title: Question 19
list.content: Which of the following statements about atomic structure isincorrect?A.\hspace{1em}The atomic nucleus contains over99.9%99.9\%99.9%of an atom's mass.B.\hspace{1em}The number of neutrons in an atom typically increases as the atomic number increases.C.\hspace{1em}The mass of an electron is approximately1/18361/18361/1836of a proton's mass.D.\hspace{1em}Electrons orbit the nucleus in fixed orbits, similar to planets orbiting the Sun.
list.markScheme: DExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​While early models of the atom, such as Bohr's atomic model, proposed that electrons move in fixed circular orbits around the nucleus, modern quantum mechanics has replaced this idea. Instead of fixed paths, electrons exist in probability clouds called orbitals, where their exact location cannot be determined. These orbitals are described by quantum mechanics, where electrons behave more like waves than particles in fixed orbits. Therefore, the idea of electrons orbiting the nucleus like planets is an outdated model that does not accurately describe atomic structure.

list.title: Question 20
list.content: Which of the following correctly describes the forces that hold an atom together?A.\hspace{1.em}Electrostatic attraction holds protons and neutrons together in the nucleus, while the strong nuclear force keeps electrons bound to the nucleus.B.\hspace{1.em}The strong nuclear force holds protons and neutrons together in the nucleus, while electrostatic attraction keeps electrons bound to the nucleus.C.\hspace{1.em}Gravitational forces play a significant role in keeping electrons in orbit around the nucleus, along with electrostatic attraction.D.\hspace{1.em}The strong nuclear force is responsible for holding the entire atom together, including the electrons.
list.markScheme: BExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​The correct explanation is that the strong nuclear force holds protons and neutrons together in the nucleus, while electrostatic attraction keeps electrons bound to the nucleus.The strong nuclear force is one of the four fundamental forces of nature and is responsible for overcoming the repulsion between positively charged protons, keeping them bound together with neutrons inside the nucleus. Without this force, the protons would repel each other due to their positive charges. On the other hand, electrostatic attraction is responsible for keeping negatively charged electrons bound to the positively charged nucleus. This force is much weaker than the strong nuclear force but is crucial for maintaining atomic structure. Contrary to one of the incorrect options, gravitational forces are negligible at the atomic scale, and the strong nuclear force does not play a role in keeping electrons attached to the nucleus.

list.title: Question 21
list.content: [Maximum marks: 6]Lead white is a pigment historically used by artists to achieve a warm white. It is no longer commonly used today due to its toxicity.A sample from one painting was analyzed, and it was found that the lead pigment contained two isotopes of lead with mass numbers 206 and 208, in a ratio of3:2.3:2.3:2.Define the term isotope.[1]Calculate the relative atomic mass of lead in the sample. Show your working[2]In another pigment sample, the relative atomic mass of lead was determined to be 207.6.Suggest why the relative atomic masses differ between the samples.[1]Predict and explain whether the lead present in both samples would have the same physical and chemical properties.[2]
list.markScheme: two atoms with the same number of protons and  different number of neutrons✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​Isotopes are atoms of the same element (so they have the same number of protons), but they have different numbers of neutrons, which means they have different mass numbers. This affects the atomic mass but not the chemical behavior.(206.0)(3)+(208.0)(2)5\dfrac{(206.0)(3) + (208.0)(2)}{5}5(206.0)(3)+(208.0)(2)​OR(206.0)(60)+(208.0)(40)100✓\dfrac{(206.0)(60) + (208.0)(40)}{100}\ \checkmark100(206.0)(60)+(208.0)(40)​✓206.8✓206.8\ \checkmark206.8✓Further Explanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The relative atomic mass is the weighted average of the mass of each isotope. With a3:23:23:2ratio, the percent abundance is60:40.60:40.60:40.Ar=∑mass of isotope×percent abundance100A_r = \sum \dfrac{\text{mass of isotope}\times \text{percent abundance}}{100}Ar​=∑100mass of isotope×percent abundance​Ar=(206.0)(60)+(208.0)(40)100=206.8A_r = \dfrac{(206.0)(60) + (208.0)(40)}{100} = 206.8Ar​=100(206.0)(60)+(208.0)(40)​=206.8any of the following:different sources/geological origins of the lead✓\checkmark✓different manufacturing/refining processes used to prepare pigments✓\checkmark✓small sample size so different distribution of isotopes✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​Different lead samples can come from different mines or regions, and the natural abundance of isotopes varies slightly depending on the geological source. That is why one sample could have more206Pb,^{206}\ce{Pb},206Pb,while another has more208Pb.^{208}\ce{Pb}.208Pb.chemical properties same: same number of electrons/same electron configuration✓\checkmark✓physical properties may differ: different mass/boiling point/density/rate of diffusion✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The chemical properties would be the same because both isotopes of lead have the same number of electrons. Chemical reactions depend on the electron arrangement, not the number of neutrons. However, the physical properties (like mass, density, diffusion rate, boiling/melting points) would be different due to the difference in mass.

list.title: Question 22
list.content: What is the relative atomic mass,ArA_rAr​, of an unknown element found in a meteorite with the isotopic abundances shown below?Isotope% Abundance39X^{39}\ce{X}39X80.040X^{40}\ce{X}40X1.041X^{41}\ce{X}41X19.0A.\hspace{1em}39.00B.\hspace{1em}40.00C.\hspace{1em}39.39D.\hspace{1em}40.50
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Based on calculations, the relative atomic mass ofX\ce{X}Xis:Ar=(39×80.0)+(40×1.00)+(41×19.00)100=39.39A_r = \dfrac{\left(39\times 80.0\right)+\left(40\times 1.00\right)+(41\times 19.00\ )}{100} = 39.39Ar​=100(39×80.0)+(40×1.00)+(41×19.00)​=39.39Students are not required to work out the calculation. theArA_rAr​cab be estimated to be close to 39 due to the high percent abundance of that isotope, but slightly higher due to the existence of the more massive isotopes.

list.title: Question 23
list.content: Lithium is a low-density alkali metal that reacts vigorously with water.Given the below data and referring to the periodic table, calculate the relative abundances of the isotopes of lithium.[3]IsotopeAtomic Mass6Li^{6}\textrm{Li}6Li6.0157Li^{7}\textrm{Li}7Li7.016State the definition of an isotope.[1]Outline the concept of relative abundance.[1]
list.markScheme:
Let x be the relative abundance of Lithium-7 and (100-x) be the relative abundance of lithium-6.Periodic table shows relative atomic mass of Lithium is 6.94.✓\checkmark✓Therefore,7.016x+6.015(100−x)100=6.947.016x+601.5−6.015x100=6.947.016x+601.5−6.015x=6941.001x+601.5=694x=92.4\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{7.016x + 6.015(100-x)}{100} &= 6.94 \\
\dfrac{7.016x + 601.5 - 6.015x}{100} &= 6.94 \\
7.016x + 601.5 - 6.015x &= 694 \\
1.001x + 601.5 &= 694 \\
x &= 92.4 %
\end{aligned}1007.016x+6.015(100−x)​1007.016x+601.5−6.015x​7.016x+601.5−6.015x1.001x+601.5x​=6.94=6.94=694=694=92.4​The relative abundances of each isotope are7.6 %✓\checkmark✓for Li-6 and92.4 %✓\checkmark✓for Li-7.Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​100 - 92.4 = 7.6Isotopes are atoms of an element with the same number of protons but with different number of neutrons.✓\checkmark✓AwardfullmarkifsamenumberofprotonsANDdifferentnumberofneutronsmentioned\textit{Award full mark if same number of protons AND different number of neutrons mentioned}Award full mark if same number of protons AND different number of neutrons mentionedRelative abundance is the percent abundance in nature of a particular isotope.✓\checkmark✓

list.title: Question 24
list.content: Element Y has 4 stable isotopes. The table below shows the relative abundance and atomic masses of these isotopes.IsotopePercent abundanceAtomic mass11.40 %203.97224.10 %205.97322.10 %206.98452.40 %207.98Calculate the relative atomic mass of the element.[2]Identify the element.[1]The atom of the element can form an ion with a charge of 4+. Determine the number of electrons in the ion.[1]Determine the nuclear symbol of another corresponding ion of element Y given the numbers of subatomic particles: electrons = 80; neutrons = 122.[1]
list.markScheme: Relative atomic mass of Element Y = (203.97) (0.014) + (205.97) (0.241)+ (206.98) (0.221) + (207.98)(0.524) =207.2✓\checkmark✓✓\checkmark✓Award2marksforcompletecorrectanswer\textit{Award 2 marks for complete correct answer}Award 2 marks for complete correct answer.Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​Relative atomic mass is the sum of each atomic mass of each isotope multiplied by its percentage abundance.Lead (Pb)✓\checkmark✓Acceptnameand/orsymbol\textit{Accept name and/or symbol}Accept name and/or symbolFurther Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The element with a relative atomic mass equal to 207.2 is Lead.78✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The element is lead (Pb). Lead has an atomic number of 82. This means that a neutral atom of lead has 82 protons and 82 electrons. Its atom loses 4 electrons (82-4) and becomes a cation with a charge of 4+(Pb4+^{4+}4+).Nuclear symbol:X82204X2822204PbX2+\ce{^{204}_{82}Pb^{2+}}X82204​X2822204​PbX2+✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​There are 80 electrons in the corresponding ion. This means that the atom has lost 2 electrons and has a become an ion of charge 2+.Mass number = protons + neutrons = 82 + 122 = 204

list.title: Question 25
list.content:
Given below is the mass spectrum of the stable isotopes of rubidium (Rb). What is the relative atomic mass of rubidium?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6e3db916-1d81-4664-9ab6-a5028574d644/images/627f7e43-e21d-4f9a-830f-cb78841ea511/CH0053.png)

A.\hspace{1em}85.5B.\hspace{1em}86.7C.\hspace{1em}85.9D.\hspace{1em}87.4
list.markScheme:
AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The approximate height of each peak is the relative abundance of each isotope.\hspace{4em}Rb–\text{--}–85∼\sim∼75 %\hspace{4em}Rb–\text{--}–87∼\sim∼25 %Rb–\text{--}–85 is the most abundant isotope within a large difference, therefore,  the relative atomic mass should be closer to 85 than 87. 85.5 is the most reasonable answer.Mathematically, we can calculate the weighted average of the mass:m=75100×85+25100×87=75100×85+25100×(85+2)=75100×85+25100×85+25100×2=85+25100×2=85.5\begin{aligned} m &= \dfrac{75}{100}\times 85 + \dfrac{25}{100}\times 87\\
\\
 &= \dfrac{75}{100}\times 85 + \dfrac{25}{100}\times (85+2)\\
 \\
&= \dfrac{75}{100}\times 85 + \dfrac{25}{100}\times 85 + \dfrac{25}{100}\times 2\\
\\
&   = 85 +  \dfrac{25}{100}\times 2 = 85.5\\
\end{aligned}m​=10075​×85+10025​×87=10075​×85+10025​×(85+2)=10075​×85+10025​×85+10025​×2=85+10025​×2=85.5​

list.title: Question 26
list.content: Element Y has a greater atomic number than element X whilst X has a greater relative atomic mass than element Y. What is the most likely explanation?A.\mbox{}\\[-48pts]The relative atomic mass on an element is determined by the number of protons and neutrons and increases with increasing atomic number.B.\mbox{}\\[-48pts]He relative atomic mass of an element is determined by the number of isotopes of an element and increases with increasing isotopes per element.C.\mbox{}\\[-48pts]The relative atomic mass of an element is determined by the mass and abundance of its isotopes.D.\mbox{}\\[-38pts]The relative atomic mass of an element is determined by its most abundant isotope.
list.markScheme: CExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​The relative atomic mass of an element is determined by the mass and abundance of its isotopes. Even though element Y has a higher atomic number, element X has a greater relative atomic mass because its isotopes are heavier on average.Real examples can be found with argon and potassium or cobalt and nickel.181818\\Ar\LARGE{\textrm{Ar}}Ar\\39.95\ \ \ \ \ 39.95\ \ \ \ \39.95191919\\K\LARGE{\textrm{K}}K\\39.10\ \ \ \ \ 39.10 \ \ \ \ \39.10\ \ \ \ \272727\\Co\LARGE{\textrm{Co}}Co\\58.93\ \ \ \ \ 58.93\ \ \ \ \58.93282828\\Ni\LARGE{\textrm{Ni}}Ni\\58.69\ \ \ \ \ 58.69\ \ \ \ \58.69\\elementatomic number /\\number of protonsmost common isotopenumber of neutronsargon18argon−40-40−4022potassium19potassium−39-39−3920cobalt27cobalt−59-59−5932nickel28nickel−58-58−5830Despite having a lower atomic number, argon has a greater relative atomic mass than potassium because its most abundant isotope is argon−40,-40,−40,with 22 neutrons while potassium has lighter isotopes like potassium−39-39−39with only 20 neutrons.  Similarly, cobalt has more neutrons than nickel so its relative atomic mass is higher than nickel's. This relative atomic mass depends more on isotopic composition than atomic number.

list.title: Question 27
list.content: Different isotopes of titanium are listed below, with their corresponding abundances found in a sample:X46X2246Ti\ce{^{46}Ti}X46​X2246​TiX47X2247Ti\ce{^{47}Ti}X47​X2247​TiX48X2248Ti\ce{^{48}Ti}X48​X2248​TiX49X2249Ti\ce{^{49}Ti}X49​X2249​TiX50X2250Ti\ce{^{50}Ti}X50​X2250​Ti% Abundance8.257.443.725.4175.18Which statement is correct for this sample?A.\hspace{1em}The calculated relative atomic mass is 47.87; the titanium is consistent with samples found on Earth.B.\hspace{1em}The calculated relative atomic mass is 49.32; the titanium is consistent with samples found on Earth.C.\hspace{1em}The calculated relative atomic mass is 49.32; the titanium may have an extraterrestrial origin.D.\hspace{1em}The calculated relative atomic mass is 48.00; the titanium may have an extraterrestrial origin.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The relative atomic mass from the isotopic abundance provided, is a weighted average of the isotope masses:Ar=46×8.25+47×7.44+48×3.72+49×5.41+50×75.18100A_r = \dfrac{46\times 8.25 + 47\times 7.44 + 48\times 3.72 + 49\times 5.41 + 50\times 75.18}{100}Ar​=10046×8.25+47×7.44+48×3.72+49×5.41+50×75.18​Ar=4931.83100=49.32A_r = \dfrac{4931.83}{100} = 49.32Ar​=1004931.83​=49.32The relative atomic mass listed for titanium in the periodic tableis 47.87 which differs from this sample with relative atomic mass 49.32. Isotopic abundances differ from one planet to another. The periodic table values are tabulated, considering the isotopic abundances on Earth. As a result, we can suggest that the sample of titanium tested may not belong to Earth.This question is categorized as medium as students must calculate the relative atomic mass from data and understand the nature of tabulated values in the periodic table.

list.title: Question 28
list.content: Which property is most likely to differ between two isotopes of the same element?A.\hspace{1em}The strength of chemical bonds they form in compounds.B.\hspace{1em}Their ability to conduct electricity in the solid state.C.\hspace{1em}Their reactivity with acids and bases.D.\hspace{1em}Their diffusion rate in gases.
list.markScheme: DExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​Isotopes have the same number of protons and electrons, meaning their chemical properties remain identical. This includes their ability to form chemical bonds and react with acids or bases. However, isotopes have different numbers of neutrons, leading to variations in their atomic mass which affects physical properties. In gases, the diffusion rate is inversely proportional to the square root of the atomic mass (as described by Graham's Law). Lighter isotopes diffuse faster than heavier isotopes, making diffusion rate the key property that differs between isotopes.While some physical properties vary between isotopes, such as density and melting point, properties like electrical conductivity remain unchanged. Conductivity depends on the movement of free electrons, which is not influenced by the nuclear mass.
